content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Simple it works

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think this would be a good addition to clash of code.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear, concise description. The problem can be solved using test set.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: The statement is too long and too simple. It won't be challenging to code at all, but it will be challenging to read. too many coin types to insert into the logic.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
To be more realistic I would suggest you change the constraints to include 0 and add test and validation case for when you have no money left.

Output section
* Please add "starting with a {{$}} sign and showing 2 decimal places".

Constraints section
* The last pair of cases is inconsistent with the second constraint. Please fix the constraint.

Thanks.

Thanks for the advice with the output.
With the constraint "amount" actually the amount from the input is meant, so it shouldn't be inconsistent with the last pair of test cases. But if it is confusing, I maybe will adapt it

I agree with you. Maybe instead of the full name  of the bill/coin one could just use its value in the description as well as in the testcases. That would make it less chunky I think.

As for the actual coding i think a test for no money (so n=0) would make the people that thought of the edge cases profit. 

As well as maybe a test with a fake bill like "25-dollar-bill". Even though that would be quite mean, it would provide another edge case. So if OP wants to add it I would suggest making it the last of the tests.

I don't know if he's changed anything since your comment, but the statement I've seen reads very quickly (not at all a challenge) and you don't even need to read it to understand (he's also specified "reverse mode").
About "too simple", we don't care since it is the same rule for everyone.

Ah sorry, my bad. Please ignore that comment.

But in that case, it's better to change 1000 to a more appropriate number to reflect the actual cases covered, e.g. 100 instead of 1000.
